comment._content: FAntastic photo...weird to look at that and think every single person in it is now dead....

comment.author: 8783399@N04
comment._content:
Thats a bit morbid SandyEm lol.

This was when there was a concrete 'velodrome' around the edge of the oval. In the early 1900s they actually ran professional motorcycle races on the track under lights in front of upwards of 40,000 people.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Click on the purl and then click again on the pic. This takes you to the SLNSW web-site, where this pic appears with several others which were evidently taken at the same time. The SLNSW caption accompanying this pic is: 'Scenes of the crowd at the Sydney Cricket Ground during the first test between Australia and England which began on 13 December 1901.'

It's a beaut pic.

Cheers

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: nla.gov.au/nla.news-page5339329 - the T&CJ indicates this pic was taken at the Sydney Cricket Ground on Saturday 13 December 14 December, 1901 [see date correction below!] during the second day of the Australia v England test match. If you click on the purl and go to the larger version of this pic at the SLNSW web-site, you can see that the clock on the members' stand appears to indicate ca. 4.20. Per the match report which appeared in the SMH the following Monday, the Australian first innings commenced at 4.19 on the Saturday afternoon...so if the T&CJ have the day right and if I've read the clock correctly, this pic might have been taken at about the time the Australian openers (Clem Hill and Victor Trumper) went in to bat. Per the SMH report the crowd grew to a then record of 36,000 during the afternoon - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article14429077 If you click on the purl (which takes you to the SLNSW web-site) and then view the album, you can see that it contains all four of the pics which appeared in the T&CJ...along with two other closer views of spectators in the stands - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/album/albumView.aspx?acmsID=153370&amp... ; If you zoom in on the 4th of the T&CJ pics (which includes a view of the scoreboard) you can see the English total at 416/8...per the SMH report, England were 351/6 at lunch on the second day, so presumably these six SLNSW album pics were taken during the course of the Saturday afternoon. One of the closer view pics shows a brass band in action! This was the first match of the 1901-1902 England v Australia test series...and just to get the convicts hopping, England won convincingly in 3 days by an innings and 24 runs! Yet despite the ordinary start, Australia in fact won the 1901-1902 series 4-1. During the second and third tests of the series, South Australian batsman Clem Hill made three consecutive scores of 99, 98 and 97. If you're a cricket tragic ('beyond hope' category), the SLNSW has an extensive collection of cricket pics on their web-site...But I'm only interested in cricket as a cultural and social phenomenon so I'm not going there (!) Also see this pic - www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2609378489/ Here's the Sydney Mail's coverage - news.google.com/newspapers?id=ygFQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=-5QDA...

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Just to rewind a bit, here's the Sydney Mail's coverage of the English team's arrival in Sydney in November 1901, along with pics taken during the subsequent match against NSW. There's a good pic of the members watching the action hidden away on p. 1383 - news.google.com/newspapers?id=xwFQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=-5QDA... ; Although NSW won this match by 53 runs, it was a good hit out for the tourists, with Archie Maclaren making 145 in the England 1st innings and L.C. Braund taking 12 wickets for the match, being well supported by Sydney Barnes. All three were later to figure in England's victory in the first test.

comment.realname: State Library of New South Wales

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/statelibraryofnsw] Woops!...I made a mistake...I must have been too busy watching the game...well that's my excuse. As you can see, the T&CJ article refers to the Saturday but doesn't give a date...I should have put Saturday 14th December, 1901.
